occurrences.sentence: Mr. Ernest Worthing.
How are you, my dear Ernest?
I think that is rather mean of you, Ernest, I must say.
Besides, your name isn’t Jack at all; it is Ernest.JACK.
It isn’t Ernest; it’s Jack.ALGERNON.
You have always told me it was Ernest.
I have introduced you to everyone as Ernest.
You answer to the name of Ernest.
You look as if yourname was Ernest.
It is perfectly absurd your saying that your name isn’tErnest.
[Taking it from case.]‘Mr. Ernest Worthing, B. 4, The Albany.’
I’ll keep this as a proof thatyour name is Ernest if ever you attempt to deny it to me, or toGwendolen, or to any one else.
Well, my name is Ernest in town and Jack in the country, and thecigarette case was given to me in the country.
I’ll reveal to you the meaning of that incomparable expression as soonas you are kind enough to inform me why you are Ernest in town and Jackin the country.
Why are you Ernest in town andJack in the country?JACK.

And as a high moral tone can hardlybe said to conduce very much to either one’s health or one’s happiness,in order to get up to town I have always pretended to have a youngerbrother of the name of Ernest, who lives in the Albany, and gets intothe most dreadful scrapes.
You have invented a very useful younger brother called Ernest, in orderthat you may be able to come up to town as often as you like.
So I am goingto get rid of Ernest.
The fact isconstantly mentioned in the more expensive monthly magazines, and hasreached the provincial pulpits, I am told; and my ideal has always beento love some one of the name of Ernest.
The moment Algernon first mentionedto me that he had a friend called Ernest, I knew I was destined to loveyou.
My own Ernest!JACK.
But you don’t really mean to say that you couldn’t love me if my namewasn’t Ernest?GWENDOLEN.
But your name is Ernest.JACK.
Personally, darling, to speak quite candidly, I don’t much care aboutthe name of Ernest . . .
The only really safe name is Ernest.JACK.
What wonderfully blue eyes you have,Ernest!
By the way, did you tell Gwendolen the truth about your being Ernest intown, and Jack in the country?JACK.
What about the profligate Ernest?JACK.
My poor brother Ernest is carried off suddenly, inParis, by a severe chill.
Miss Cardew was a little too muchinterested in your poor brother Ernest?
Ernest, we may never be married.
Mr. Ernest Worthing has just driven over from the station.
‘Mr. Ernest Worthing, B. 4, The Albany,W.’ Uncle Jack’s brother!
Ask Mr. Ernest Worthing to come here.
You, I see from your card, areUncle Jack’s brother, my cousin Ernest, my wicked cousin Ernest.ALGERNON.
Your brother Ernest dead?JACK.
Poor Ernest!
Your brother Ernest.
Ernest hasjust been telling me about his poor invalid friend Mr. Bunbury whom hegoes to visit so often.
Uncle Jack, if you don’t shake hands with Ernest I will never forgiveyou.JACK.
I have put Mr. Ernest’s things in the room next to yours, sir.
Mr. Ernest’s luggage, sir.
Mr. Ernest has been suddenlycalled back to town.MERRIMAN.
I think your frankness does you great credit, Ernest.
But pray, Ernest, don’t stop.
Oh, don’t cough, Ernest.
I daresay it wasfoolish of me, but I fell in love with you, Ernest.ALGERNON.
Yes, you’ve wonderfully good taste, Ernest.
You need hardly remind me of that, Ernest.
‘To-day I broke off my engagement with Ernest.
You must not laugh at me, darling, but it had always been a girlishdream of mine to love some one whose name was Ernest.
I pity any poor married woman whose husband is notcalled Ernest.ALGERNON.
I might respect you, Ernest, I might admire your character,but I fear that I should not be able to give you my undividedattention.
Ernest has astrong upright nature.
I beg your pardon, Gwendolen, did you say Ernest?GWENDOLEN.
Oh, but it is not Mr. Ernest Worthing who is my guardian.
Ernest never mentioned to me that he had abrother.CECILY.
Of course you are quite, quite surethat it is not Mr. Ernest Worthing who is your guardian?CECILY.
Mr. Ernest Worthing and I areengaged to be married.GWENDOLEN.
Mr. Ernest Worthing is engaged to me.
Ernest proposed to me exactly ten minutes ago.

It would distress me more than I can tell you, dear Gwendolen, if itcaused you any mental or physical anguish, but I feel bound to pointout that since Ernest proposed to you he clearly has changed his mind.GWENDOLEN.
Do you suggest, Miss Fairfax, that I entrapped Ernest into anengagement?
Ernest!
My own Ernest!JACK.
Here is Ernest.ALGERNON.
A moment, Ernest!
Where is your brother Ernest?
Weare both engaged to be married to your brother Ernest, so it is amatter of some importance to us to know where your brother Ernest is atpresent.JACK.
However, I will tellyou quite frankly that I have no brother Ernest.
Besides I have just made arrangementswith Dr. Chasuble to be christened at a quarter to six under the nameof Ernest.JACK.
I madearrangements this morning with Dr. Chasuble to be christened myself at5.30, and I naturally will take the name of Ernest.
We can’t both be christened Ernest.
Lieutenant1840, Captain, Lieutenant-Colonel, Colonel, General 1869, Christiannames, Ernest John.
I always told you, Gwendolen, my name was Ernest, didn’t I?
Well, it is Ernest after all.
I mean it naturally is Ernest.
Yes, I remember now that the General was called Ernest, I knew I hadsome particular reason for disliking the name.
GWENDOLEN.Ernest!
My own Ernest!
[Enter Jack.]
Divorces are made inHeaven—[Jack puts out his hand to take a sandwich.
‘From little Cecily,with her fondest love to her dear Uncle Jack.’
Besides, your name isn’t Jack at all; it is Ernest.JACK.
It isn’t Ernest; it’s Jack.ALGERNON.
Well, my name is Ernest in town and Jack in the country, and thecigarette case was given to me in the country.
I’ll reveal to you the meaning of that incomparable expression as soonas you are kind enough to inform me why you are Ernest in town and Jackin the country.
Why are you Ernest in town andJack in the country?JACK.
[Sees Jack and bows to him with icy coldness.]ALGERNON.
[Gwendolen and Jack sit downtogether in the corner.]
[Exchanges glances with Jack.]
[Jack looks at her in amazement.]
I think Jack, for instance, a charming name.
GWENDOLEN.Jack? . . .
No, there is very little music in the name Jack, if any atall, indeed.
I have known several Jacks, and they all, without exception, weremore than usually plain.
Besides, Jack is a notorious domesticity forJohn!
She and Jackblow kisses to each other behind Lady Bracknell’s back.
[Goes out, looking back at Jack.]
Jack looks perfectly furious, and goes to the door.]
By the way, did you tell Gwendolen the truth about your being Ernest intown, and Jack in the country?JACK.
[Jack and Gwendolen go off.]
[Enter Jack.
[Jack looks indignantly at him, and leaves the room.
Dear Uncle Jack is so very serious!
I wish Uncle Jack would allow that unfortunate young man, his brother,to come down here sometimes.
‘Mr. Ernest Worthing, B. 4, The Albany,W.’ Uncle Jack’s brother!
You, I see from your card, areUncle Jack’s brother, my cousin Ernest, my wicked cousin Ernest.ALGERNON.
Uncle Jack won’t be backtill Monday afternoon.
Well, I know, of course, how important it is not to keep a businessengagement, if one wants to retain any sense of the beauty of life, butstill I think you had better wait till Uncle Jack arrives.
I certainly wouldn’t let Jack buy my outfit.
Uncle Jack is sending you toAustralia.ALGERNON.
[Enter Jack slowly from the back of the garden.
[Jack presses his hand convulsively.]
Uncle Jack!
[Cecily goes towards Jack; he kisses her brow in amelancholy manner.]CECILY.
What is the matter, Uncle Jack?
And you will shake hands withhim, won’t you, Uncle Jack?
They come slowly up to Jack.]JACK.
[Jack glares at him and does not take hishand.]CECILY.
Uncle Jack, you are not going to refuse your own brother’s hand?JACK.
Uncle Jack, do be nice.
Uncle Jack, if you don’t shake hands with Ernest I will never forgiveyou.JACK.
[They all go off except Jack and Algernon.]JACK.
What a fearful liar you are, Jack.
I thought you were withUncle Jack.ALGERNON.
Uncle Jack would be very much annoyed if he knew you were staying ontill next week, at the same hour.
Oh, I don’t care about Jack.

Well, ever since dear Uncle Jack first confessed to us that he had ayounger brother who was very wicked and bad, you of course have formedthe chief topic of conversation between myself and Miss Prism.
I suppose one of the many good elderly women who areassociated with Uncle Jack in some of his philanthropic work in London.
[Enter Jack.]GWENDOLEN.
This is Uncle Jack.GWENDOLEN.
Jack!
Jack and Algernon groan and walk up and down.]CECILY.
Your brother is a little off colour, isn’t he, dear Jack?
I don’t think there is much likelihood, Jack, of you and Miss Fairfaxbeing united.JACK.
[He seizes the muffin-dishfrom Jack.]JACK.
Jack, you are at the muffins again!
[Jack groans, and sinks into a chair.
[Enter Jack followed byAlgernon.
[To Jack.]
[Turns to Jack.]
[Jack looks perfectlyfurious, but restrains himself.]JACK.
[Glares at Jack for a few moments.
[Looking rather puzzled, and pointing to Jack and Algernon.]
Algernon and Jack pretend to be anxious to shieldCecily and Gwendolen from hearing the details of a terrible publicscandal.]
[ExitJack in great excitement.]
Uncle Jack seems strangely agitated.CHASUBLE.
[Enter Jack with ahand-bag of black leather in his hand.]
And, speaking of the science of Life, have you got the cucumbersandwiches cut for Lady Bracknell?LANE.
Lady Bracknell and Miss Fairfax.
Enter Lady Bracknell andGwendolen.]
[Lady Bracknell and Algernon go into the music-room, Gwendolen remainsbehind.]JACK.
And I would like to be allowed to take advantage of Lady Bracknell’stemporary absence . .
[EnterLady Bracknell.]
She and Jackblow kisses to each other behind Lady Bracknell’s back.
Lady Bracknelllooks vaguely about as if she could not understand what the noise was.
Thank you, Lady Bracknell, I prefer standing.
I know nothing, Lady Bracknell.
The fact is, Lady Bracknell, I said Ihad lost my parents.
Yes, Lady Bracknell.
I reallythink that should satisfy you, Lady Bracknell.
You can hardly imagine that I andLord Bracknell would dream of allowing our only daughter—a girl broughtup with the utmost care—to marry into a cloak-room, and form analliance with a parcel?
[Lady Bracknell sweeps out in majestic indignation.]JACK.
I don’t really know what a Gorgon is like, but I am quitesure that Lady Bracknell is one.
My father is Lord Bracknell.
Lady Bracknell!JACK.
[Enter Lady Bracknell.
I am engaged to be married to Gwendolen, Lady Bracknell!
[Lady Bracknell bows coldlyto Cecily.]ALGERNON.
Mr. Moncrieff and I are engaged to be married, Lady Bracknell.
They areopen to your inspection, Lady Bracknell.
How extremely kind of you, Lady Bracknell!
Goodbye, Lady Bracknell.
When I married Lord Bracknell I had no fortuneof any kind.
Thank you, Lady Bracknell.
I beg your pardon for interrupting you, Lady Bracknell, but thisengagement is quite out of the question.
It pains me very much to have to speak frankly to you, Lady Bracknell,about your nephew, but the fact is that I do not approve at all of hismoral character.
That is very generous of you, Lady Bracknell.

Pray excuse me, Lady Bracknell, for interrupting you again, but it isonly fair to tell you that according to the terms of her grandfather’swill Miss Cardew does not come legally of age till she is thirty-five.LADY BRACKNELL.
But my dear Lady Bracknell, the matter is entirely in your own hands.
Lord Bracknellwould be highly displeased if he learned that that was the way in whichyou wasted your time and money.
This matter may prove to beone of vital importance to Lord Bracknell and myself.
Miss Prism, Lady Bracknell, has been for the last threeyears Miss Cardew’s esteemed governess and valued companion.
[Catches sight ofLady Bracknell, who has fixed her with a stony glare.
Twenty-eight years ago, Prism, you left Lord Bracknell’shouse, Number 104, Upper Grosvenor Street, in charge of a perambulatorthat contained a baby of the male sex.
Lady Bracknell, I admit with shame that I do not know.
What do you think this means, Lady Bracknell?LADY BRACKNELL.
[Pointing toLady Bracknell.]
Lady Bracknell, I hate to seem inquisitive, but wouldyou kindly inform me who I am?LADY BRACKNELL.
But I see dear Dr. Chasuble coming up through the garden.
Dr. Chasuble!
[Enter Canon Chasuble.]
I think itwould do her so much good to have a short stroll with you in the Park,Dr. Chasuble.
[Goes down the garden with Dr. Chasuble.]CECILY.
Miss Prism and Dr. Chasuble return.]
You are too much alone, dear Dr. Chasuble.
[Dr. Chasuble starts.]
Dr. Chasuble, I hope you are well?CHASUBLE.
Ah! that reminds me, you mentioned christenings I think, Dr. Chasuble?
[Dr. Chasuble looksastounded.]
Dr. Chasuble is a most learned man.
Besides I have just made arrangementswith Dr. Chasuble to be christened at a quarter to six under the nameof Ernest.JACK.
I madearrangements this morning with Dr. Chasuble to be christened myself at5.30, and I naturally will take the name of Ernest.
I should think itextremely probable I never was, and so does Dr. Chasuble.
[Enter Dr. Chasuble.]
I don’t think that, as things are now, it would be of much practicalvalue to either of us, Dr. Chasuble.CHASUBLE.
I dare not even suspect, Dr. Chasuble.
Dr. Chasuble,my unfortunate brother.
MISS PRISM.
MISS PRISM.Do not speak slightingly of the three-volume novel, Cecily.
They depressme so much.MISS PRISM.
And was your novel everpublished?MISS PRISM.
Mr. Worthing, Isuppose, has not returned from town yet?MISS PRISM.
MISS PRISM.Egeria?
Ishall see you both no doubt at Evensong?MISS PRISM.
But is a man not equally attractive when married?MISS PRISM.
Mr. Worthing?MISS PRISM.
MISS PRISM.More shameful debts and extravagance?CHASUBLE.
I mean, of course, you are continually christening, aren’tyou?MISS PRISM.
Oh yes.MISS PRISM.
But where did you deposit thehand-bag?MISS PRISM.Do not ask me, Mr. Worthing.
What railway station?MISS PRISM.
mother!MISS PRISM.
[Embraces her]MISS PRISM.
Old Mr. Thomas Cardew, whoadopted me when I was a little boy, made me in his will guardian to hisgrand-daughter, Miss Cecily Cardew.

The late Mr. Thomas Cardew, an old gentleman of a very charitable andkindly disposition, found me, and gave me the name of Worthing, becausehe happened to have a first-class ticket for Worthing in his pocket atthe time.
In what locality did this Mr. James, or Thomas, Cardew come across thisordinary hand-bag?JACK.
Miss Cardew was a little too muchinterested in your poor brother Ernest?
You are not to talk of Miss Cardew like that.
My nameis Cecily Cardew.GWENDOLEN.
Cecily Cardew?
Do you allude to me, Miss Cardew, as an entanglement?
Cecily and Gwendolen glare at eachother.]GWENDOLEN.Are there many interesting walks in the vicinity, Miss Cardew?CECILY.
Quite a well-kept garden this is, Miss Cardew.CECILY.
I am known forthe gentleness of my disposition, and the extraordinary sweetness of mynature, but I warn you, Miss Cardew, you may go too far.CECILY.
I felt there was some slight error, Miss Cardew.
As for your conduct towards Miss Cardew, I must say that your taking ina sweet, simple, innocent girl like that is quite inexcusable.
There is certainly no chance of your marrying Miss Cardew.ALGERNON.
That lady is Miss Cecily Cardew, my ward.
Mr. Worthing, is Miss Cardew at allconnected with any of the larger railway stations in London?
Miss Cardew is the grand-daughter of the lateMr. Thomas Cardew of 149 Belgrave Square, S.W.; Gervase Park, Dorking,Surrey; and the Sporran, Fifeshire, N.B.LADY BRACKNELL.
Miss Cardew’s family solicitors are Messrs. Markby, Markby, and Markby.

I havealso in my possession, you will be pleased to hear, certificates ofMiss Cardew’s birth, baptism, whooping cough, registration,vaccination, confirmation, and the measles; both the German and theEnglish variety.
As a matterof form, Mr. Worthing, I had better ask you if Miss Cardew has anylittle fortune?JACK.
Miss Cardew seems to me a mostattractive young lady, now that I look at her.
There are distinct social possibilities in Miss Cardew’s profile.
I am Miss Cardew’s guardian,and she cannot marry without my consent until she comes of age.

Pray excuse me, Lady Bracknell, for interrupting you again, but it isonly fair to tell you that according to the terms of her grandfather’swill Miss Cardew does not come legally of age till she is thirty-five.LADY BRACKNELL.

My dear Mr. Worthing, as Miss Cardew states positively that she cannotwait till she is thirty-five—a remark which I am bound to say seems tome to show a somewhat impatient nature—I would beg of you to reconsideryour decision.JACK.
Miss Prism, Lady Bracknell, has been for the last threeyears Miss Cardew’s esteemed governess and valued companion.
[Lane is arranging afternoon tea on the table, and after the music hasceased, Algernon enters.]ALGERNON.
Lane?LANE.
by theway, Lane, I see from your book that on Thursday night, when LordShoreman and Mr. Worthing were dining with me, eight bottles ofchampagne are entered as having been consumed.
I don’t know that I am much interested in your familylife, Lane.
That will do, Lane, thank you.
[Lane goes out.]
Lane’s views on marriage seem somewhat lax.
[Enter Lane.]LANE.
[Lane goes out_.
[Enter Lane.]
[Enter Lane with the cigarette case on a salver.
Lane goes out.]
[Enter Lane.]LANE.
Lane!
[Enter Lane.]LANE.Miss Fairfax.
[To Lane, who now enters.]
[Lane presents several letters on a salver to Algernon.
A glass of sherry, Lane.
To-morrow, Lane, I’m going Bunburying.
I hope to-morrow will be a fine day, Lane.
Lane, you’re a perfect pessimist.
Lane goes off.]
LADY BRACKNELL.
Mamma!LADY BRACKNELL.
Twenty-nine.LADY BRACKNELL.
Between seven and eight thousand a year.LADY BRACKNELL.
In investments, chiefly.LADY BRACKNELL.
Whatnumber in Belgrave Square?JACK.149.LADY BRACKNELL.
LADY BRACKNELL.To lose one parent, Mr. Worthing, may be regarded as a misfortune; tolose both looks like carelessness.
In a hand-bag.LADY BRACKNELL.A hand-bag?JACK.
Miss Cardew is the grand-daughter of the lateMr. Thomas Cardew of 149 Belgrave Square, S.W.; Gervase Park, Dorking,Surrey; and the Sporran, Fifeshire, N.B.LADY BRACKNELL.
Yes, Aunt Augusta!LADY BRACKNELL.
LADY BRACKNELL.Never speak disrespectfully of Society, Algernon.
LADY BRACKNELL.To speak frankly, I am not in favour of long engagements.

Pray excuse me, Lady Bracknell, for interrupting you again, but it isonly fair to tell you that according to the terms of her grandfather’swill Miss Cardew does not come legally of age till she is thirty-five.LADY BRACKNELL.
What do you think this means, Lady Bracknell?LADY BRACKNELL.
Lady Bracknell, I hate to seem inquisitive, but wouldyou kindly inform me who I am?LADY BRACKNELL.
At the time when Miss Prism left me in the hand-bag, had I beenchristened already?LADY BRACKNELL.
Letme know the worst.LADY BRACKNELL.
Yes, but what was my father’s Christian name?LADY BRACKNELL.
Eating asusual, I see, Algy!ALGERNON.
I have no doubt about that, dear Algy.
What do you mean, Algy, by Cecily!
Just giveit back to me, Algy.ALGERNON.
My dear Algy, you talk exactly as if you were a dentist.
My dear Algy, I don’t know whether you will be able to understand myreal motives.
That, my dear Algy, is the whole truth pureand simple.ALGERNON.
Forgoodness’ sake don’t play that ghastly tune, Algy.
I beg your pardon, Algy, Isuppose I shouldn’t talk about your own aunt in that way before you.
Youdon’t think there is any chance of Gwendolen becoming like her motherin about a hundred and fifty years, do you, Algy?ALGERNON.
Algy, kindly turn your back.
Algy, you always adopt a strictly immoral attitude towards life.
Algy, you may turn round now.
Oh, that’s nonsense, Algy.
You young scoundrel, Algy, you must get out of this place as soon aspossible.
if my name was Algy, couldn’t you love me?CECILY.
You won’t beable to run down to the country quite so often as you used to do, dearAlgy.
Algy, I wish to goodness you would go.
CECILY.Algy, could you wait for me till I was thirty-five?ALGERNON.
Algy’s elder brother!
Algy, you young scoundrel, you will have totreat me with more respect in the future.
Algy!
Mr. Ernest Worthing.
[Taking it from case.]‘Mr. Ernest Worthing, B. 4, The Albany.’
Mr. Ernest Worthing has just driven over from the station.
‘Mr. Ernest Worthing, B. 4, The Albany,W.’ Uncle Jack’s brother!
Ask Mr. Ernest Worthing to come here.
Oh, but it is not Mr. Ernest Worthing who is my guardian.
Of course you are quite, quite surethat it is not Mr. Ernest Worthing who is your guardian?CECILY.
Mr. Ernest Worthing and I areengaged to be married.GWENDOLEN.
Mr. Ernest Worthing is engaged to me.
I may mention that I have always suspected you of being aconfirmed and secret Bunburyist; and I am quite sure of it now.JACK.
Bunburyist?
What on earth do you mean by a Bunburyist?ALGERNON.
I have Bunburyed all over Shropshireon two separate occasions.
What you really are is a Bunburyist.
Iwas quite right in saying you were a Bunburyist.
You are one of themost advanced Bunburyists I know.JACK.
I haveinvented an invaluable permanent invalid called Bunbury, in order thatI may be able to go down into the country whenever I choose.
Bunbury isperfectly invaluable.
If it wasn’t for Bunbury’s extraordinary badhealth, for instance, I wouldn’t be able to dine with you at Willis’sto-night, for I have been really engaged to Aunt Augusta for more thana week.JACK.
Besides, now that I know you to be a confirmed Bunburyist Inaturally want to talk to you about Bunburying.
I’m not a Bunburyist at all.
Nothing will induce me to part with Bunbury, and if you ever getmarried, which seems to me extremely problematic, you will be very gladto know Bunbury.
A man who marries without knowing Bunbury has a verytedious time of it.JACK.
If I marry a charming girl like Gwendolen, and she isthe only girl I ever saw in my life that I would marry, I certainlywon’t want to know Bunbury.
It is a great bore, and, I need hardly say, a terrible disappointmentto me, but the fact is I have just had a telegram to say that my poorfriend Bunbury is very ill again.
This Mr. Bunbury seems to suffer from curiously badhealth.
Yes; poor Bunbury is a dreadful invalid.
Well, I must say, Algernon, that I think it is high time that Mr.Bunbury made up his mind whether he was going to live or to die.
I should be much obliged if you wouldask Mr. Bunbury, from me, to be kind enough not to have a relapse onSaturday, for I rely on you to arrange my music for me.
I’ll speak to Bunbury, Aunt Augusta, if he is still conscious, and Ithink I can promise you he’ll be all right by Saturday.
To-morrow, Lane, I’m going Bunburying.
You can put up my dressclothes, my smoking jacket, and all the Bunbury suits . . .
Oh, I’m a little anxious about poor Bunbury, that is all.JACK.
If you don’t take care, your friend Bunbury will get you into a seriousscrape some day.
Ernest hasjust been telling me about his poor invalid friend Mr. Bunbury whom hegoes to visit so often.
he has been talking about Bunbury, has he?CECILY.
Yes, he has told me all about poor Mr. Bunbury, and his terrible stateof health.JACK.Bunbury!
Well, I won’t have him talk to you about Bunbury or aboutanything else.
I don’t allow any Bunburying here.
This Bunburying, as you call it, has not been a great success for you.
But I must see her before I go, and makearrangements for another Bunbury.
This ghastly state of things is what you call Bunburying, I suppose?ALGERNON.
Yes, and a perfectly wonderful Bunbury it is.
The most wonderfulBunbury
Well, you’ve no right whatsoever to Bunbury here.
One has a right to Bunbury anywhere one chooses.
Everyserious Bunburyist knows that.JACK.
Serious Bunburyist!
I happen to be serious about Bunburying.
Well, the only small satisfaction I have in the whole of this wretchedbusiness is that your friend Bunbury is quite exploded.
May I ask if it is in this house that your invalid friend Mr. Bunburyresides?ALGERNON.
Bunbury doesn’t live here.
Bunbury is somewhereelse at present.
In fact, Bunbury is dead.
When did Mr. Bunbury die?
I killed Bunbury this afternoon.
I mean poor Bunbury diedthis afternoon.
What did he die of?ALGERNON.Bunbury?
I was not awarethat Mr. Bunbury was interested in social legislation.
The doctors found outthat Bunbury could not live, that is what I mean—so Bunbury died.

Andnow that we have finally got rid of this Mr. Bunbury, may I ask, Mr.Worthing, who is that young person whose hand my nephew Algernon is nowholding in what seems to me a peculiarly unnecessary manner?JACK.
Oh! merely Aunt Augusta and Gwendolen.JACK.
My dear fellow, the way you flirt with Gwendolen is perfectlydisgraceful.
It is almost as bad as the way Gwendolen flirts with you.JACK.
I am in love with Gwendolen.
The bread and butter is forGwendolen.
Gwendolen is devoted to bread and butter.JACK.
My dear fellow, Gwendolen is my first cousin.
I’ll keep this as a proof thatyour name is Ernest if ever you attempt to deny it to me, or toGwendolen, or to any one else.
If Gwendolen accepts me, I am going tokill my brother, indeed I think I’ll kill him in any case.
If I marry a charming girl like Gwendolen, and she isthe only girl I ever saw in my life that I would marry, I certainlywon’t want to know Bunbury.
Now, if I get her out of the wayfor ten minutes, so that you can have an opportunity for proposing toGwendolen, may I dine with you to-night at Willis’s?JACK.
Enter Lady Bracknell andGwendolen.]
[To Gwendolen.]
[Gwendolen and Jack sit downtogether in the corner.]
Won’t you come and sit here, Gwendolen?GWENDOLEN.
Gwendolen, you willaccompany me.GWENDOLEN.
[Lady Bracknell and Algernon go into the music-room, Gwendolen remainsbehind.]JACK.
You really love me, Gwendolen?GWENDOLEN.
Well, really, Gwendolen, I must say that I think there are lots ofother much nicer names.
Gwendolen, I must get christened at once—I mean we must get married atonce.
Gwendolen!GWENDOLEN.
Gwendolen, will you marry me?
While I am makingthese inquiries, you, Gwendolen, will wait for me below in thecarriage.
In the carriage, Gwendolen!
[Gwendolen goes to the door.
Gwendolen, the carriage!GWENDOLEN.
A girl with a simple,unspoiled nature, like Gwendolen, could hardly be expected to reside inthe country.JACK.
I need hardly say Iwould do anything in the world to ensure Gwendolen’s happiness.
You don’t mean to say Gwendolenrefused you?
Oh, Gwendolen is as right as a trivet.
Youdon’t think there is any chance of Gwendolen becoming like her motherin about a hundred and fifty years, do you, Algy?ALGERNON.
By the way, did you tell Gwendolen the truth about your being Ernest intown, and Jack in the country?JACK.
Have you told Gwendolen yet that you have an excessively pretty wardwho is only just eighteen?JACK.
Cecily and Gwendolenare perfectly certain to be extremely great friends.
[Enter Gwendolen.
Gwendolen, upon my word!GWENDOLEN.
Really, Gwendolen, I don’t think I can allow this at all.

Worthing is a place in Sussex.
Mr. Worthing, I confess I feel somewhatbewildered by what you have just told me.
